awd_titl_txt: CAREER: BrCl and Other Highly Reactive Brominating Agents in Disinfected Waters: Implications for Disinfection By-Product Formation and Control
awd_abstract_narration:
Title:  CAREER: BrCl and Other Highly Reactive Brominating Agents in Disinfected Waters: Implications for Disinfection By-Product Formation and Control

PI Name:  John D. Sivey

Proposal Number:  CBET - 1651536 

Bromide is present in virtually all natural waters. When these waters are disinfected prior to use as drinking water or in swimming pools, bromide can be converted into several highly reactive brominating agents. The primary objective of this project will be to understand how these brominating agents can react with naturally occurring organic compounds to generate potentially toxic disinfection by-products. In the educational outreach program sixth-grade math students will explore how linear functions are essential to science and engineering. The overarching goal of this program will be to use inquiry-based, hands-on water chemistry activities to help sixth-grade students connect the mathematics they are learning to real-world scientific questions and careers.

The reactive bromine species in chlorinated drinking water is typically assumed to be HOBr; nevertheless, several additional bromine species can readily form when bromide-containing waters are disinfected with chlorine, including BrCl, BrOCl, and Br2O (collectively, BrX). Despite being highly reactive toward a range of organic compounds, the influence of BrX on formation of brominated disinfection byproducts (DBPs) has received little attention. This project will quantify the influence of individual BrX species on formation rates, yields, and product distributions of several classes of DBPs, including trihalomethanes, haloacetic acids, halophenols, and halosalicylic acids. Humic acid, natural organic matter surrogates, and natural surface waters will serve as sources of organic DBP precursors. Experimental data will be used to develop models describing the effects of bromine speciation on DBP formation.  By evaluating the influence of bromine speciation on DBP formation, the PI will seek to improve our understanding of DBP generation and control measures. As human activities, population growth, and climate change increase halide levels in drinking water (which can, in turn, promote formation of BrX), the importance of understanding bromination processes will be particularly acute. Increased understanding of DBP chemistry will promote societally relevant outcomes, notably the sustainability of drinking water supplies as well as environmental stewardship of other disinfected aqueous systems (e.g., wastewater, ballast water, desalination systems, and swimming pools).  The educational component of this project will involve an interdisciplinary K-12 outreach program, entitled "The Mathematics of Color and Light." This program will deliver hands-on, inquiry-based learning activities to sixth-grade math students and will emphasize concepts of light absorption and linear functions. The program will emphasize the role of bleach in water treatment. High school science students, undergraduate researchers, and K-12 teachers will serve as co-facilitators of this program. In total, this project will impact approximately 600 middle school students, 60 high school co-facilitators, several K-12 teachers, and 12 undergraduate students over five years.

por.por_cntn:
Bromide ion is present most natural waters. When waters are chlorinated, as is common for drinking water and swimming pools, bromide can be converted into a complex mixture of reactive brominating agents. This project seeks to understand how these brominating agents can react with carbon-based compounds present in natural waters to generate potentially toxic disinfection byproducts (DBPs). This project also includes an educational outreach program in which 6th grade math students explore how linear equations are essential to science and engineering. The overarching goal of this program is to use inquiry-based, hands-on water chemistry activities to help 6th grade students connect the mathematics they are learning to real-world scientific questions and careers.

Intellectual Merits

Bromine reactivity depends strongly on the chemical composition of the solution. This study has examined how the structure of organic compounds can have a pronounced influence on how these compounds react with brominating agents to form DBPs. This project also demonstrated how chloride ion (a so-called “spectator ion”) can substantially increase the reactivity of bromine by promoting the conversion of less reactive brominating agents such as HOBr into much more potent chemicals such as BrCl. Understanding how solution conditions (such as chloride levels) can influence bromine reactivity is important, especially as drinking water sources become enriched in chloride due to applications of road deicing salts and seawater intrusion into groundwater.

New method for measuring chlorine, bromine, and bromide. This project pioneered a new method for selectively measuring chlorine and bromine in water by using 1,3,5-trimethoxybenzene (TMB) as a derivatizing agent. These method advancements are important because classical approaches to measuring bromine are unable to distinguish chlorine from bromine. This work also demonstrated the usefulness of TMB for measuring bromide, even when present at much lower concentrations than other ions such as chloride (as is typical of seawater).

Surprising reaction pathways. This study is the first to demonstrate that monobrominated organic compounds can, upon chlorination, generate polybrominated DBPs, including trihalomethanes. The presumed pathway involves “ipso substitution”, in which chlorine replaces bromine on an aromatic compound. The liberated bromine can go on to react of brominated compounds to form DBPs with more than one bromine atom. Such a shuffling of bromine and chlorine is important to understand because brominated DBPs are generally more toxic than their chlorinated counterparts.

Broader Impacts

Student training in a multidisciplinary and diverse environment.  Eight (8) high school students, 24 undergraduate students, and one graduate (MS) student were trained on this project at the interface of environmental engineering, environmental chemistry, and analytical chemistry. These students included substantial representation from women and underrepresented groups.

Enhancing STEM education. Several aspects of this project enhanced STEM education at multiple levels, including junior high, high school, undergraduate, and graduate education. A key aspect of the project was using a hands-on, guided-inquiry water chemistry program to help junior high school students understand how the mathematics they are learning is relevant and important to scientific and engineering careers. Student surveys demonstrated significantly more favorable student perceptions following their participation in the program when asked their level of agreement with the following statements: (1) I enjoy learning about science. (2) Once I get to high school, I would like to take a lot of science classes. (3)  I can see myself studying science-related fields (such as chemistry, biology, healthcare, math, or engineering) in college.

When the results are grouped by the participants’ gender, additional insights are obtained. Current interest and anticipated retention of interest in science had similar, positive correlations among female and male participants. However, interest in mathematics and the perceived synergy between math and science is largely unchanged among female participants whereas male participants report a positive change for both prompts. Future careers plans related to STEM had a stronger positive correlation for male participants relative to female participants.

This project also pioneered best practices for conducting online, collaborative training meetings spanning multiple universities. These best practices were shared with other educators through a publication in the journal Environmental Engineering Science.  

Training of future faculty members.  This project supported the development and delivery of a three-day, online symposium entitled Preparing for Faculty Positions at Primarily Undergraduate Institutions (PUIs). 

•    Session #1 – Preparing for Teaching Success at a PUI – https://youtu.be/-TUeHnULmhM  

•    Session #2 – Preparing for Research Success at a PUI – https://youtu.be/17_NMgI7rMU   

•    Session #3 –Preparing Successful Applications for Faculty Positions at PUIs – https://youtu.be/zRQiNUgm63c  

Promoting societally relevant outcomes.   Brominated DBPs are potentially toxic to users of disinfected drinking water, pool water, and spa water. Brominated DBPs are generally more toxic than their chlorinated counterparts. The results of this work are anticipated to inform new strategies for minimizing DBP formation and thereby minimize DBP exposure to humans and to the environment.
